pages.title: About
pages.intro:
Hi! I'm Bren, and I'm a Senior Front End Developer. I'm passionate about building robust, accessible software while empowering my teams to become strongly capable, compassionate developers.

I'm a software engineer. I'm a father. I'm neuro-divergent. I'm a musician. I'm a photographer.

sections.title: What do I care most about?

cards.title: People.
cards.content: As a developer, people are the heart of everything I do. I don't build software for the sake of building software. I build software to help people. All people. It's my duty as a developer to make sure that my deliverables are accessible to everyone through empathy and a deep understanding of WCAG standards. It's also my duty to build and enable capable, diverse and inclusive teams that can deliver robust, thoughtfully designed and rigoursly tested projects.

sections.title: What are my core skills?
sections.content:
First and foremost, I am a skilled front-end practitioner with over 15 years experience working in web development, and over 25 years working in IT. Among my skills I pride myself on:

  • Front-end development
  • Testing
  • Accessibility
  • Mentoring and leading teams of developers

cards.title: Front-end development
cards.content:
My happy place is working on the front end. This is the point where I can add the most value to the end user and realise the design vision of my team. I enjoy working with:

  • JavaScript & TypeScript
  • React, Vue, React Context, Redux, React Query & Pinia
  • Accessible HTML
  • CSS to wizardry levels

cards.title: Testing
cards.content:
I enjoy breaking my code down into tiny, easy to test pieces which ensures a more robust end product. I'm familiar with and proficient in:

  • Jest for functional unit testing
  • React Testing Library for component testing
  • Playwright & Cypress for end-to-end and UI testing
  • Manual accessibility testing.

cards.title: Accessibility
cards.content: As a neuro-diverse person in tech, I'm incredibly passionate about accessibility and this is at the front of my mind for all interfaces I work on. I'm constantly thinking about who might be interacting with my deployed code and how any visual, auditory or physical processing impairments might affect their application interactions.

cards.title: Mentoring and leading
cards.content:
I might have mentioned it, but I love leading and growing people. I have a great variety of mentoring and teaching experience including:

  • Mentoring junior and intermediate developers across a range of organisations
  • Creating a co-leading front-end education sessions at BNZ
  • Teaching JS & React development to new developers at Dev Academy Aotearoa
  • Facilitating learning for children in tech through Code Club Aotearoa
  • 10 years leading, mentoring and teaching through the New Zealand Cadet Forces.

Searching for perfection is madness. I know this to be true, but my near-perfect role would be one where I get to focus on developer experience (DX) as well as user experience (UX). It would include:

  • Building and maintaining design systems - At the heart of every great front-end is a solid design system. This space affords me the opportunity to improve UX and accessibility (A11y) while bringing a more cohesive and consistent feel to user interfaces. It also helps to improve DX and make life easier for my peers.
  • Testing, testing and more testing - I love a good unit test, especially when those unit tests are strongly focused around A11y. This is why I love Testing Library so much!
  • A cohesive plan - I work best when there's a plan in place, or where I have time to help make a plan. "Rushing to market" or making hasty decisions can lead to unnecessary accumulation of technical debt - which never leads to a good time. I feel happiest when living somewhere between sensible levels of pragmatism and crystal clear direction.

sections.title: What else can I tell you?

cards.content: I mentioned neuro-divergence. I was diagnosed with ADHD in 2023 and I believe this to be a superpower. It influences my ability to dive deep, learn rapidly, and to empathise with users of all abilities. It's also a challenge some days - though I feel fairly self-aware of my limitations. Specifically, my auditory processing is probably my biggest weakness. I always hear what is being said, but sometimes just need some time to process before giving a complete response. The infamous "are there any questions" can sometimes lead to me looking a bit like a deer in the headlights. I like being given the opportunity to step away and process information before swinging back around with questions or opinions.

sections.title: Do you think I'd be a good fit for your team?
sections.content: Let's chat! I'm always open to a conversation about new opportunities. I love meeting new people and learning about their experiences. If you think I might be a good fit for your team, please reach out!

pages.title: Work history
pages.intro: I've worked in tech for a quarter century now, honing my skills in general development, database development and administration and have found my happy place in the Front End Web space. Here's a quick run down of my most recent roles.

sections.title: Storypark
sections.content: Senior Front End Engineer - July 2024 to present

cards.title: Outline
cards.content: Storypark is a platform that connects teachers, parents and children in early childhood education. I'm currently working as a Senior Front End Engineer, building and maintaining the front end of the platform.

cards.title: Responsiblities
cards.content:
• Building and maintaining the front end of the Storypark platform using Vue, Vuetify and Pinia
  • Working with a team of engineers, designers and product managers to deliver new features and improvements
  • Expanding the Storypark Pattern Library to aid other developers in building new features and migrating existing features from Rails
  • Ensuring the platform is accessible to all users
  • Ensuring the platform is tested to a high standard

cards.title: Achievements
cards.content:
• Improving unit test coverage throught the Single Page App codebase
  • Improving the accessibility of the platform through incremental changes to it's pattern library

sections.title: BNZ
sections.content: Senior Front End Developer - November 2021 to July 2024

cards.title: Outline
cards.content: Originally a 6 month contract, I worked with BNZ as a Senior Front End Developer across multiple teams over more than two and a half years.

cards.title: Responsiblities
cards.content:
• Replacement of "legacy" banking systems with React applications
  • Building React applications as micro-frontends in a shell / mini-app architecture
  • Contributing to both mini-apps and the shell application
  • Tesing of all code using Jest, Testing Library and Playwright
  • Improving code quality and solving technical debt using Sonarqube
  • Advocating for and promoting self-directed hackathon discovery days
  • Mentoring and training developers in React development
  • Mentoring and training developers in unit, end-to-end and user interface testing

cards.title: Acheivements
cards.content:
• Developing and co-leading structured front end learning sessions for peers
  • Research and planning implementation of MSW (Mock Service Worker) for development, unit, UI & E2E testing
  • Advocating for self-directed hackathon days, given technical staff room for growth

sections.title: Dev Academy Aoteroa (formerly Enspiral Dev Academy)

cards.title: Outline
cards.content: For 12 months I trained and mentored around 100 students in their first step to becoming junior developers. This was an incredibly special role for me due to Dev Academy's strong focus on soft skills which enabled me to learn so much more about people and about myself.

cards.title: Responsiblities
cards.content:
• Creating and delivering daily training sessions
  • Facilitating personal and professional development for students
  • Just-in-time professional development in order to pass on skills to students
  • Personally guiding subsets of each cohort through 1-on-1 mentoring covering both technical skills and personal wellbeing

cards.title: Acheivements
cards.content:
• Introducing CSS to the curriculum
  • Contributing positively to the careers of so many developers
